channel.title: Leak causing bastardness
channel.description:
I share a car with my mum, and it's always had problems when ever we get a lot of rain. For example the engine sometimes doesn't start properly after its been raining, and when you press the gas it dry humps the road and stalls.
Few weeks ago the back seat had become very wet (I wish it was from sexual times A-har-har!, however it wasn't), I looked in the trunk and low and behold the matting was as wet as spongebob squarepants. I cleared out the matting.
It's obvious that I have a leak however I can't for the life of me find it.
It was raining heavily earlier today and I was about to get in, tried to open the doors, they wouldn't open. The central locking was fucked and wasn't unlatching the doors.
So it's obvious that the car is letting in water somewhere, and obviously this water is fucking with the electrical systems.
Sorry for long post but does anyone know how I can sort this out?

item.title: Leak causing bastardness
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Davidude, post:10, topic:312019”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=408463.msg3016337#msg3016337 date=1257212837]
The reason a car is hard to start or runs bad when it is wet outside is because you have a crack in your distributor cap, replace it and you should be good.

As to the inside leak (which is probably unrelated), check around the windows and the door and trunk seals, those are most likely the problem.
[/quote]
Crack in distributor cap? I’ll have a look. I’m pretty sure it isn’t any of the seals though, me and my granddad went over them with a fine tooth comb. Oh and apparently it’s not going to the garage now. I’ll report back later.[/quote]

It can be so small you can’t see it but water vapor can still get through. Our distributor caps here for most cars cost about $12, it may be a good idea just to replace it.

Read full topic

item.title: Leak causing bastardness
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

dont use dye like that idiot said u dont want fuckin purple seats, however using a bucket of water u can find some leaks, i doubt its anything to do with the distributor cap, more likely to be shorting some wires (hence the central locking not working, and possibly fucking with the ignition resulting in a possible misfire?)

Read full topic

item.title: Leak causing bastardness
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

If the locking system is acting weird and the back seats are wet, isn’t a leaky door an obvious cause? The water could be getting in anywhere but might not wet all the shit around it because the metal and rubber channeling could take the water lower down to soak into the seats.

Or maybe it’s the sunroof? It could be anything really… just try chucking water over it or something to try to see where it comes in.

I don’t really know much about cars, I’m just suggesting some ideas.

Read full topic

item.title: Leak causing bastardness
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Davidude, post:12, topic:312019”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=408463.msg3016618#msg3016618 date=1257245024]
You can check for yourself. If the bottom is all rusty, it’s almost a certainty that the plate is where it’s leaking from.
[/quote]
I don’t know though, how would the water be going upwards? I understand when your driving water would be spraying up from the wheels but the problem only happen after it’s been left in the rain parked for a night. Hmm[/quote]

I’ve seen a lot of cars that had a leaking bottom plate and with wet back seats and trunk. Maybe your car has a leak somewhere else though.

Read full topic

item.title: Leak causing bastardness
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Davidude, post:5, topic:312019”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=408463.msg3015513#msg3015513 date=1257158757]
I bet it’s the bottom plate that’s leaking. What car is it?
[/quote]
peugeot 106


like dis one.

Bottom plate is underneath the car, right? That’d make sense because we can’t find a leak anywhere on top.[/quote]
Off topic: Did anyone else notice the license plate looks like it says RS27FAG?

The reason a car is hard to start or runs bad when it is wet outside is because you have a crack in your distributor cap, replace it and you should be good.

As to the inside leak (which is probably unrelated), check around the windows and the door and trunk seals, those are most likely the problem.

item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

Well I would try and have a look now but it’s dark outside because of bastard sun going behind the horizon. Then when the sun is coming back up it is being taken to a garage so some fat men can fix it.

item.title: Leak causing bastardness
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

It’s underneath the car, yes. What you could do is look underneath the car and poke with your fingers on the bottom plate (I call it the bottom plate, but I have no idea what the actual name for it is. Just the plate underneath your car.)

Your best bet is to visit a garage. Most will take a look, without charging a dime.

Read full topic

item.title: Leak causing bastardness
item.dc:creator: @Thebeanie TheBeanie
item.description:
@Thebeanie wrote:

hmm put Dye in a bucket of water and pour it over the car, Different areas at a time… that should help narrow down where the leak is

Read full topic

item.title: Leak causing bastardness
item.dc:creator: @chrisn2323 chrisn2323
item.description:
@chrisn2323 wrote:

In autotech class a guy had a similar leak where the spoiler was attached to the trunk. We put this black silicon goo on the connection and it didn’t leak anymore.

check for those type of spots.

Read full topic
